definitions: large bird that hunts and feeds on other animals using sharp talons and hooked beak
extinct carnivorous dinosaur characterized by sharp claws and teeth for hunting prey
examples: The raptor circled high above scanning for small mammals below
Wildlife rehabilitators nursed the injured raptor back to health
Fossil evidence shows raptors hunted in coordinated packs
The velociraptor was a small but deadly raptor species

definitions: overwhelming feeling of intense pleasure, happiness, or emotional excitement
spiritual state of mystical union with divine presence leading to transcendent joy
examples: She listened to the symphony in complete rapture
The crowd watched in rapture as the meteor shower filled the sky
The mystic described experiencing divine rapture during meditation
Religious paintings often depict saints in states of rapture

definitions: object, person, or occurrence that is unusual, scarce, or seldom encountered
state or quality of being rare, uncommon, or difficult to find
examples: Finding an honest politician is a rarity these days
The museum displayed several rarities from ancient civilizations
The rarity of the gemstone significantly increased its value
Snow in the desert is a rarity worth documenting

definitions: playful troublemaker, especially a child who behaves badly but in an amusing way
unscrupulous or dishonest person who engages in deceitful behavior
examples: The little rascal hid his sister's favorite doll again
Those rascals toilet-papered the principal's house on Halloween
The rascal swindled dozens of elderly people out of their savings
Don't trust that rascal with your credit card information

definitions: area of reddened, irritated, or inflamed skin often with bumps or spots
sudden appearance or occurrence of many similar things at once
examples: The doctor examined the red rash spreading across her arms
An allergic reaction caused a painful rash on his neck
The city experienced a rash of burglaries last month
There was a rash of resignations after the scandal broke

definitions: rough metal tool with raised teeth used for shaping wood or metal
harsh grating sound produced by rough surfaces rubbing together
examples: The carpenter used a rasp to smooth the chair's curved edges
She selected a fine rasp for the delicate woodwork
His voice had a rasp from shouting at the game
The rasp of metal against concrete hurt their ears

definitions: small red or black aggregate fruit growing on thorny bushes with tart sweet flavor
rude sound made by blowing air through lips to express contempt or mockery
examples: She picked fresh raspberries for the morning smoothie
Wild raspberries grow along the hiking trail every summer
The audience gave the performer a raspberry after the terrible joke
He blew a loud raspberry at his teasing brother

definitions: long-tailed rodent larger than a mouse often considered a pest
person who betrays friends or associates for personal gain
person who provides information to authorities about criminal activities
examples: The rat scurried across the subway platform at midnight
Laboratory rats are commonly used in medical research
I can't believe that rat sold us out to save himself
He proved himself a rat by breaking our agreement
The gang suspected someone was a rat feeding information to police
Nobody trusts a rat in the criminal underworld

definitions: toothed wheel or bar that allows movement in one direction only
process of gradual increase or decrease that proceeds in fixed increments
examples: The ratchet mechanism prevents the cable from unwinding
He tightened the strap using the ratchet buckle
Interest rates continued their upward ratchet throughout the year
The ratchet effect made reversing the policy nearly impossible

definitions: quantity or amount measured per unit of something else like time or space
fixed price charged for a specific service or commodity
standard or level used to assess quality, value, or performance
examples: The heart rate increased during intense exercise
Crime rates have fallen significantly this decade
Hotel rates double during the tourist season
The bank offered competitive mortgage rates
This restaurant deserves a five-star rate for its service
The movie received poor rates from critics

definitions: official act of confirming or validating an agreement, treaty, or decision through formal consent
examples: The treaty awaits ratification by the senate next month
Ratification of the amendment required a two-thirds majority vote
Union members voted for ratification of the new contract
The board's ratification made the policy officially binding

definitions: numerical or categorical assessment of quality, performance, or suitability
official classification indicating appropriate audience or security clearance level
examples: The app received a rating of 4.8 stars from users
Credit ratings determine loan eligibility and interest rates
The movie received an R rating for violence and language
His security rating allowed access to classified documents

definitions: quantitative relation between two amounts showing how many times one value contains another
examples: The ratio of students to teachers is fifteen to one
Mix the ingredients in a ratio of two parts flour to one part sugar
The golden ratio appears frequently in art and nature
Financial ratios help investors evaluate company performance

definitions: fixed amount of food or supplies officially allowed to each person
controlled distribution of scarce resources especially during shortages or war
examples: Each soldier received a daily ration of food and water
The expedition packed emergency rations for two weeks
During the war, sugar rations were strictly enforced
The government introduced fuel rations during the energy crisis

definitions: being capable of reasoning and making decisions based on logic rather than emotion
examples: Humans are considered rational beings capable of complex thought
Any rational person would see the flaws in that argument
The philosopher argued that we are not purely rational creatures
Rational beings must take responsibility for their choices

definitions: set of reasons or logical basis for a course of action, decision, or belief
examples: The committee explained their rationale for rejecting the proposal
What's your rationale for choosing this expensive option?
The rationale behind the policy change wasn't clearly communicated
She provided a detailed rationale for her research methodology

definitions: psychological process of creating logical explanations for behaviors motivated by unacceptable feelings
process of reorganizing a business or system to increase efficiency and reduce waste
examples: His explanation was just a rationalisation for his selfish behavior
Rationalisation helps people cope with cognitive dissonance
The company's rationalisation resulted in three factories closing
Rationalisation of the supply chain reduced costs significantly

definitions: philosophical belief that reason and logic are the primary sources of knowledge and truth
examples: Descartes is considered a founder of modern rationalism
Rationalism contrasts with empiricism in epistemological debates
The Enlightenment embraced rationalism over religious dogma
His rationalism led him to reject supernatural explanations

definitions: person who believes that reason and logic are the chief sources of knowledge
examples: The rationalist argued against accepting claims without evidence
Famous rationalists include Spinoza and Leibniz
As a rationalist, she demanded logical proof for every assertion
Rationalists often clash with those who prioritize faith

definitions: quality of being based on clear reasoning, logic, and sound judgment rather than emotion
examples: The rationality of her argument convinced even the skeptics
Economic models often assume perfect rationality in decision-making
Stress can temporarily impair our rationality
The debate centered on the limits of human rationality

definitions: psychological process of constructing logical justification for decisions originally made for other reasons
reorganization of business operations or processes to improve efficiency and reduce costs
examples: His explanation was mere rationalization of his impulsive purchase
Rationalization is a common defense mechanism in psychology
The rationalization plan eliminated redundant departments
Post-merger rationalization saved the company millions annually

definitions: system of limiting the amount of food, fuel, or goods each person can have during shortages
examples: Wartime rationing ensured everyone received basic necessities
Water rationing was implemented during the severe drought
The hospital began rationing medical supplies during the crisis
Rationing prevented hoarding and ensured fair distribution

definitions: tropical climbing palm with long flexible stems used in furniture making
furniture or objects made from woven strips of rattan palm stems
examples: Rattan grows abundantly in Southeast Asian rainforests
The rattan vine can grow over 100 meters long
The patio furniture was made from durable rattan
She bought a rattan basket at the craft market

definitions: rapid succession of short sharp sounds from loose parts shaking
toy that makes noise when shaken, typically given to babies
sound-producing structure at the end of a rattlesnake's tail
examples: The rattle of dishes announced the earthquake's arrival
We heard a rattle coming from the car's engine
The baby shook her rattle enthusiastically
Colorful rattles help develop infant motor skills
The snake's rattle warned hikers to stay back
Each segment adds to the rattlesnake's rattle

definitions: informal term for a rattlesnake, a venomous snake with a rattle on its tail
examples: The cowboy spotted a rattler coiled beside the trail
Rattlers are common in the southwestern desert regions
A six-foot rattler was removed from the backyard
The rattler's distinctive sound serves as a warning

definitions: venomous American snake with a series of horny rings on its tail that rattle as warning
examples: The rattlesnake coiled defensively when threatened
Diamondback rattlesnakes are found throughout the Southwest
A rattlesnake bite requires immediate medical attention
The distinctive rattle helps identify rattlesnakes from other species

definitions: continuous rapid succession of short sharp knocking sounds
remarkably good or impressive in an old-fashioned informal sense
examples: The rattling of windows woke everyone during the storm
Constant rattling from the loose pipe annoyed the neighbors
They told a rattling good story around the campfire
It was a rattling performance by the orchestra

definitions: extensive damage or destruction caused by natural forces, war, or disease
examples: The ravages of time were evident on the ancient monument
Coastal communities suffered the ravages of the hurricane
Years of war left ravages throughout the countryside
The ravages of addiction destroyed his once-promising career

definitions: act of causing severe and extensive damage or destruction to something
examples: The ravaging of forests threatens countless species
Years of ravaging by invaders left the city in ruins
The ravaging effects of climate change are increasingly visible
Ravaging floods destroyed entire villages

definitions: large dance party featuring electronic music and often lasting all night
extravagantly enthusiastic review or praise for something
examples: Thousands attended the weekend rave in the warehouse district
Underground raves became popular in the 1990s
The restaurant received raves from food critics
Her performance earned raves from the audience

definitions: confused or complicated tangle of threads, fibers, or other material
examples: She patiently untangled the ravel of yarn
The fishing line had become a hopeless ravel
The ravel of electrical cords behind the desk needed organizing
Wind had created a ravel in her long hair

definitions: large black bird of the crow family known for intelligence and distinctive croaking call
examples: A raven perched on the castle's ancient tower
Ravens are highly intelligent problem-solving birds
The raven's call echoed across the misty moor
Ravens can live for over twenty years in the wild

definitions: deep narrow valley with steep sides typically formed by running water erosion
examples: The hikers carefully descended into the rocky ravine
A stream flowed through the bottom of the ravine
The ravine separated the two mountain villages
Flash floods are dangerous in desert ravines

definitions: wild irrational talking typically associated with delirium or madness
expression of extreme enthusiasm or admiration for something
examples: His fevered ravings made no sense to the nurses
The patient's ravings subsided after medication
She's been raving about that new restaurant all week
Critics are raving about the director's latest film

definitions: natural or unprocessed state of materials before refinement or preparation
examples: The factory processes raw materials into finished products
Artists often prefer working with raw canvas
Raw data needs analysis before drawing conclusions
The documentary showed raw footage from the war zone

definitions: stiff untanned leather from cattle or buffalo hide used for various purposes
examples: The drum was made with stretched rawhide
Cowboys used rawhide lariats for roping cattle
Dog chews made from rawhide help clean teeth
Native Americans traditionally used rawhide for many tools

definitions: narrow beam of light or radiation emanating from a source
flat-bodied cartilaginous fish related to sharks with wing-like fins
straight line extending from a point in one direction in geometry
examples: Rays of sunlight filtered through the forest canopy
X-rays revealed the fracture in her ankle
The stingray glided gracefully across the ocean floor
Manta rays can grow to enormous sizes
Draw a ray from point A extending through point B
The angle is formed by two rays sharing a vertex

definitions: manufactured textile fiber made from regenerated cellulose that resembles silk
examples: The dress was made from soft flowing rayon
Rayon wrinkles easily and requires careful washing
Vintage rayon shirts are popular with collectors
The fabric blend contained cotton and rayon

definitions: act of completely destroying a building or structure down to ground level
examples: The razing of old buildings made way for new development
Protesters opposed the razing of the historic theater
The razing took weeks to complete safely
After the razing, only rubble remained

definitions: sharp-edged instrument used for shaving hair from skin or other surfaces
examples: He replaced the blade in his safety razor
Electric razors are convenient for travel
The barber stropped his straight razor before shaving
She used a razor to remove pills from her sweater

definitions: runs batted in, a statistic crediting a batter for making a play that allows a run to score
examples: He led the league with 142 RBIs last season
The grand slam added four RBIs to his total
Her clutch hitting produced three RBIs in the championship
RBI leaders often bat in the middle of the lineup

definitions: distance to which someone or something can extend or stretch
extent or range of someone's influence, power, or authority
examples: The ladder wasn't tall enough to reach the roof
Keep medicines beyond the reach of children
The company's reach extends across five continents
Social media expanded the reach of their message

definitions: action of stretching out to touch, grasp, or arrive at something
examples: Reaching for the top shelf required a stepladder
The reaching of an agreement took months of negotiation
After years of reaching for success, she finally achieved it
The constant reaching strained his shoulder muscles

definitions: action or feeling in response to a situation, stimulus, or event
process in which substances interact to form new substances with different properties
opposition to political or social progress or reform
examples: Her reaction to the news was one of complete shock
The crowd's reaction was overwhelmingly positive
The chemical reaction produced heat and gas
Allergic reactions can range from mild to severe
The reaction against liberal policies gained momentum
Conservative reaction followed the progressive reforms

definitions: person who opposes political or social progress and wants return to previous conditions
examples: The reactionary opposed all forms of social reform
Reactionaries in parliament blocked progressive legislation
He was labeled a reactionary for his traditional views
The revolution targeted reactionaries and monarchists

definitions: tendency of a substance to undergo chemical reaction with other substances
degree to which someone responds emotionally or behaviorally to stimuli
examples: The reactivity of sodium makes it dangerous to handle
Chemical reactivity decreases down the noble gas group
Emotional reactivity can be managed through mindfulness
The child's reactivity to loud noises concerned the parents

definitions: device in which nuclear fission is initiated and controlled to produce energy
vessel or apparatus in which chemical reactions are carried out industrially
examples: The nuclear reactor provides power for the entire city
Safety systems prevent reactor meltdowns
The chemical reactor operates at high temperature and pressure
Pharmaceutical companies use specialized reactors for drug synthesis

definitions: instance or period of reading a book, document, or other written material
examples: That novel was a really enjoyable read
She finished the read in just two days
Give the report a quick read before the meeting
His latest book is a compelling read

definitions: quality of written text being easy to read and understand
examples: The document's readability improved after editing
Font choice significantly affects readability
Readability scores help writers gauge text complexity
Poor readability reduces user engagement with content

definitions: person who reads books, newspapers, or other written material
electronic device designed for reading digital books and documents
collection of texts compiled for educational purposes in a single volume
examples: She's an avid reader of mystery novels
The newspaper has millions of readers worldwide
The e-reader can store thousands of books
Her reader needs charging after eight hours
The literature reader contains excerpts from classic works
Students must purchase the required reader for class
